scenarioDescription:
The HD 106315 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 106315 is a star with 1.09 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.3 times its radius. It is located 356.66 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.48 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 106315 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 106315 system


HD 106315 b

HD 106315 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2017-06, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 106315 b is 12.606 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 106315 b is 2.440 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 106315 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 106315 c

HD 106315 c was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2017-06, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 106315 c is 15.207 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 106315 c is 4.350 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 106315 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 106315, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: HD 106315 - System With 2 Exoplanets
